interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Emma
Review Date: 2006/07/28
Store: Kate Beckinsale  (Actor),     Bernard Hepton  (Actor),     Diarmuid Lawrence  (Director)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, A&E Home Video, All A&E Titles
Product Description: ["From the producers of A&E's Emmy award winning Pride and Prejudice.", "From the greatest romantic novelist of all time comes a delightfully wicked comedy of love and matchmaking. Jane Austen's sly and vivacious heroines have enchanted readers for more than 200 years. Now, for the first time on DVD, this acclaimed production from the creators of A&E's best selling Pride and Prejudice brings to life one of the most fascinating Austen characters of all time - the charming and mischievous Emma Woodhouse.", "Starring Kate Beckinsale, Emma is the story of a rich, clever and beautiful young woman who can't resist orchestrating other people's love lives. As her romantic plans go ridiculously wrong, however, it's Emma herself who risks missing out on her perfect match!", "Join A&E for a wry visit to the drawing rooms and country manors of 19th-century England - a visit to the enchanting world of Jane Austen's Emma now in the crystal clear digital clarity of DVD."]
Average Rating: 4.4
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Romance, Comedy', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Raymond Coulthard, Bernard Hepton, Dido Miles, James Hazeldine, Samantha Morton, Prunella Scales, Guy Henry, Jane Austen, Sylvia Barter, Dominic Rowan, Kate Beckinsale, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, Diarmuid Lawrence, Andrew DaviesRaymond Coulthard, Bernard Hepton, Dido Miles, James Hazeldine, Samantha Morton, Prunella Scales, Guy Henry, Jane Austen, Sylvia Barter, Dominic Rowan, Kate Beckinsale, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, Diarmuid Lawrence, Andrew Davies  See more', 'Language': 'Unqualified, English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Stereo)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.33:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 5.38 x 0.6 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Director': 'Diarmuid Lawrence', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Release date': 'July 5, 2000', 'Actors': 'Kate Beckinsale, Bernard Hepton, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, James Hazeldine', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'A&E Home Video', 'Writers': 'Andrew Davies, Jane Austen', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: With Kate Beckinsale in the lead, this should have been a whale of a movie, especially if Ms. Beckinsale was allowed to bring some of her persona from Cold Comfort Farm in which she played a more Emma-like character there than she was allowed to do here. Beckinsale's Emma was overly moody and had none of the light cheerfulness of Austen's Emma (or Ms. Paltrow's for that matter). Mark Stong is not Jeremey Northrup but he is VERY good. Unfortunately, this movie never establishes that Mr. Knightly is a daily presence in the Woodhouse household (i.e., compare with the Northrup-Paltrow version), which is critical to understanding the relationship between Mr. Knightly and Emma. Indeed, their love for each other is nearly a shocker in this version coming in its last 10 minutes. If you are an Emma fan, you may find this film a disappointment. In general, I prefer Ms. Beckinsale over Ms. Paltrow but Ms. Paltrow's film is a better Reader's Digest adaptation of this lengthly and rich novel. I wonder if modern movie/DVD audiences have the patience for a longer 4 and 6 hour versions of this novel akin to what has been done for Pride & Prejudice by the BBC and A&E, respectively. Indeed, the latest 2-hour version of P&P by Hollywood is a bare skeleton of that incredible story.
Review Title: Not quite Miss Jane's Emma
Rating: 3.0
--------------------------------------------------

["From the producers of A&E's Emmy award winning Pride and Prejudice.", "From the greatest romantic novelist of all time comes a delightfully wicked comedy of love and matchmaking. Jane Austen's sly and vivacious heroines have enchanted readers for more than 200 years. Now, for the first time on DVD, this acclaimed production from the creators of A&E's best selling Pride and Prejudice brings to life one of the most fascinating Austen characters of all time - the charming and mischievous Emma Woodhouse.", "Starring Kate Beckinsale, Emma is the story of a rich, clever and beautiful young woman who can't resist orchestrating other people's love lives. As her romantic plans go ridiculously wrong, however, it's Emma herself who risks missing out on her perfect match!", "Join A&E for a wry visit to the drawing rooms and country manors of 19th-century England - a visit to the enchanting world of Jane Austen's Emma now in the crystal clear digital clarity of DVD."]
{'Genre': 'Romance, Comedy', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Raymond Coulthard, Bernard Hepton, Dido Miles, James Hazeldine, Samantha Morton, Prunella Scales, Guy Henry, Jane Austen, Sylvia Barter, Dominic Rowan, Kate Beckinsale, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, Diarmuid Lawrence, Andrew DaviesRaymond Coulthard, Bernard Hepton, Dido Miles, James Hazeldine, Samantha Morton, Prunella Scales, Guy Henry, Jane Austen, Sylvia Barter, Dominic Rowan, Kate Beckinsale, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, Diarmuid Lawrence, Andrew Davies  See more', 'Language': 'Unqualified, English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Stereo)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.33:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 5.38 x 0.6 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Director': 'Diarmuid Lawrence', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Closed-captioned, Color, NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 47 minutes', 'Release date': 'July 5, 2000', 'Actors': 'Kate Beckinsale, Bernard Hepton, Mark Strong, Samantha Bond, James Hazeldine', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'A&E Home Video', 'Writers': 'Andrew Davies, Jane Austen', 'Number of discs': '1'}
With Kate Beckinsale in the lead, this should have been a whale of a movie, especially if Ms. Beckinsale was allowed to bring some of her persona from Cold Comfort Farm in which she played a more Emma-like character there than she was allowed to do here. Beckinsale's Emma was overly moody and had none of the light cheerfulness of Austen's Emma (or Ms. Paltrow's for that matter). Mark Stong is not Jeremey Northrup but he is VERY good. Unfortunately, this movie never establishes that Mr. Knightly is a daily presence in the Woodhouse household (i.e., compare with the Northrup-Paltrow version), which is critical to understanding the relationship between Mr. Knightly and Emma. Indeed, their love for each other is nearly a shocker in this version coming in its last 10 minutes. If you are an Emma fan, you may find this film a disappointment. In general, I prefer Ms. Beckinsale over Ms. Paltrow but Ms. Paltrow's film is a better Reader's Digest adaptation of this lengthly and rich novel. I wonder if modern movie/DVD audiences have the patience for a longer 4 and 6 hour versions of this novel akin to what has been done for Pride & Prejudice by the BBC and A&E, respectively. Indeed, the latest 2-hour version of P&P by Hollywood is a bare skeleton of that incredible story.
Not quite Miss Jane's Emma
profile:
User Profile Summary:

- **Content Preference**: Strong interest in adaptations of classic literature, particularly by Jane Austen. Specifically engaged with works that delve into romantic themes and character development.
  
- **Format Preference**: Prefers DVD formats for movies and appreciates high-quality productions, such as those from A&E, which are known for their detailed adaptations.
  
- **Genre Interest**: Enjoys romance and comedy genres, with a focus on films that embody a wit and charm similar to Austen's work.

- **Actor Preference**: Exhibits a preference for performances by Kate Beckinsale, appreciating her acting style compared to other actresses like Gwyneth Paltrow in similar roles.

- **Critical Approach**: Tends to analyze adaptations critically, favoring faithful representations of source material, and expressing dissatisfaction when adaptations fail to capture essential elements or character dynamics.

- **Viewer Expectations**: Suspects modern audiences may prefer shorter adaptations, yet expresses a desire for more in-depth storytelling reminiscent of longer, more detailed productions.

Overall, the user values rich storytelling and character complexity, particularly in romantic narratives derived from classic literature.
